column1:
Operator: Good morning. And thank you for standing by for Bright Scholar’s 2020 First Fiscal Quarter Earnings Conference Call. At this time, all participants are in listen-only mode. After management’s prepared remarks, there will be a question-and-answer session. Today’s conference call is being recorded.I would now like to turn the meeting over to your host for today’s conference, Ms. Ruby Yim, Investor Relations Council.
Ruby Yim: Thank you, Operator. Good morning and good evening. Welcome to Bright Scholar’s first fiscal quarter ended November 30, 2019, earnings call. Joining me today are Jerry He, our Executive Vice Chairman; Derek Feng, our Chief Executive Officer; and Dora Li, our Chief Financial Officer.As a reminder, today’s conference call is being broadcast live via webcast. In addition, a replay will be available on our website following the call. By now, you should have received a copy of our press release that was distributed on January 16, 2020, after market close Eastern Time. If you have not, it is available on our IR section of our website.Before we get started, let me review the forward-looking statements regarding this conference call. Such as statements related to future, not past, events often address expected future business and financial performance and financial condition and often contain words such as will, estimate, project, predict, believe, expect, anticipate, intend, potential, plan or goal.Price column may also make written or oral forward-looking statements in other reports, in presentations, in material delivered to shareholders and in press releases. In addition, price columns representatives may make oral forward-looking statements.Forward-looking statements by the nature, adjust matters that are to different degrees uncertain, such as statements about the company’s goals and strategies, its future business development, financial condition and results of operations, its ability to retain and grow its customer base and network of schools and the grow of and trends in the markets for services in China, the demand for and the market acceptance of its brand and services, competition industry in China, relevant government policies and regulations relating to the corporate structure, business and industry, fluctuations in general economic and business conditions in China.Further information regarding this and other risks is included in Bright Scholar’s filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Bright Scholar undertakes no duty to update any forward-looking statements, except as required under applicable law.During this call, we’ll be referring to GAAP and non-GAAP measures -- financial measures. We use certain non-GAAP measures as supplemental measures to review and assess our operating performance. These non-GAAP financial measures have limitations as analytical tools and investors should not consider them in isolation or as a substitute for net income attributable to company or other consolidated statement of comprehensive income data prepared in accordance with the U.S. GAAP. Please note, all numbers are in RMB and all comparisons refer to year-over-year comparisons unless otherwise stated.With that, I’ll turn the call over to our Executive Vice Chairman, Jerry He. Jerry?
Jerry He: Thanks, Ruby. Thank you everyone who is joining our call today to review 2020 first fiscal quarter results. First and foremost, let me wish everyone a Happy New Year with every happiness, good health and a continued prosperity in 2020.Now let’s get started. For those who are new to Bright Scholar, we have included our earnings presentation of brief corporate introduction from slide five to 13, which you can download from our IR website. Again, our numbers are in R&D and our comparison referred to over year over year unless otherwise stated.I will start today’s call before pass to Derek to provide update on our business operational performance for the quarter and also share our strategic initiative for fiscal 2020. Dora will then provide a detailed financial review before we take your questions.Please turn to slide 15. We are very pleased with the tremendous progress we continue to make as we transform and scale Bright Scholar to better serve the evolving needs of our students in a fast changing education industry. The strategic investment we made across our business segments in the past years have given us a strong start to the 2020 fiscal year.We scaled our business significantly with acquire business contributed to over RMB315 million in revenue and RMB46 million in adjusted EBITDA in the first fiscal quarter of 2020. In addition, we further diversified our revenue stream as you can refer to slide 16, revenue from domestic K-12 schools only accounted for close to 61% of our total revenue in the first fiscal quarter of 2020.The impact is a transformational as we move into the next phase of our growth journey. By taking additional steps to further position Bright Scholar as a global premier education service provider.We see enormous opportunities in leveraging our global platform to expand our existing business, such as language training, college counseling, study tours and the camps. We also see the benefit of entering into career readiness market, offering career company service that will help our students post education overseas. While the initiatives are in their early stage, we believe the power of international education ecosystem we will continue to drive our long-term growth.In the 2020 fiscal year, we remain firmly focused our three fronts, first, continue to build our global network and the capitalizing our synergistic business opportunities for our domestic and overseas business.Second, continue our organic growth initiatives in accelerating ramp up to improve utilization, optimizing operational efficiency and broadening our service offerings.Third, continue to strengthen our leadership in international education by acquisition of strategic asset.Going at transformative, fiscal year 2019, we remain committed to execution our strategy and expansion opportunities to drive enhance the value for our students, employees, shareholders and stakeholders.With this note, I will turn the call to Derek. Derek?
Derek Feng: Thank you, Jerry. Good morning and good evening. We are off to a very strong start in the first fiscal. Please turn to slide 17 for our performance highlights and in slide 18 for detailed breakdown by segments.I am very pleased to report that our overall revenue grew by 69% and operating profit grew by 46.7% year-over-year. More importantly, the operating margins of our China based operations, including domestic K-12 schools and complimentary education services continue to expand.Jump to slide 27, you can find that the adjusted SG&A of headquarter have declined year-over-year despite of increasing skill and complexity of our businesses. These are the early results from the operational improvement initiatives that we started last year.Meanwhile, as we expand our business to reduce risk exposure to domestic K-12 related regulations, as well as to enhance competitive advantages our overall margin profile is also changing in the near-term driven by the different cost structure of the acquired overseas businesses.However, we have a number of initiatives underway, including setting up shared services centers in the U.K. to achieve both revenue and cost synergies among all of our business acronyms that will enhance the overall margin over time.Continue to slide 19, underpinning performance of our domestic K-12 schools was the strong enrollment growth of 25.2%, with the expansion of our school network, including the newly acquired overseas schools, our global school network increased by 29.4% to 88 schools with capacity increased by 14.6% to a total of 67,194 students. Our blended utilization of the quarter was 77%.Let’s continue on to slide 20. Our efforts to improve the effectiveness of marketing and student recruitment have yielded very positive results in driving growth in average student enrollment of domestic K-12 schools with international schools, bilingual schools and the kindergarten industries by 18.6%, 12.3% and 23.1%, respectively. Our robust performance reflects our commitment to delivering quality education as shown in slide 21.As of December 19, 2019, approximately 57.1% of students in the 2020 graduating class of our international schools have received over 310 offers from global top 50 institutions. As of the real estate, our flagship school Guangdong Country Garden School received three conditional offers from the University of Oxford, three conditional offers from the University of Cambridge, and one unconditional offer from the University of Chicago. We expect more students will receive offers from these elite institutions and the grades of our students will continue to improve across all age groups.Continue to slide 22. The deep collaboration with Country Garden is critical to expand our domestic network with an asset light model. As of the release date, we have signed 60 contracts, including five outside Country Garden contracts to operate a total of 53 kindergartens, six bilingual schools and one international school with a total capacity of approximately 29,800 students.In addition, we have made a significant progress to capture incremental growth opportunities among our businesses. First, we commenced international student recruitment for three independent schools in U.K. through CATS.Second, we launched a basketball and baseball pilot programs in two Bright Scholar schools with early success, these programs are after school and weekend activities designed for students from both Bright Scholar and local communities.Finally, our study tour programs have been well received in our own schools. In fiscal -- in the first quarter of 2020, we served over 4,000 students with 80% from Bright Scholar K-12 schools. We are extending our service offerings to better serve more students both from Bright Scholar, as well as schools outside our network.Please turn to slide 23. Driving integration of newly acquired overseas businesses is another strategic imperative. We’re setting up shared service operations in U.K. that not only could serve our business needs better, but also can significantly reduce cost.We are in Phase 1 with focused on finance, IT, human resources and legal functions, of which we’re on track to complete by the end of this fiscal year. Phase 2, would cover operation and procurement, marketing and admission, as well as risk and compliance, of which we target complete before the end of fiscal to 2021.In closing, I would like to reiterate that our number one goal remains to be helping students grow. That means continue to invest in teachers and teacher training to increase complimentary service offerings and to expand global programs that can leverage our global platform and resources. We believe that our focus on academic excellence, in addition to driving an efficient business model will produce consistent growth in revenue and in earnings for our shareholders.So, at this point, I’d like to turn the call over to Dora to discuss our financials. Dora?
Dora Li: Thank you, Derek. Let’s turn back to our financials, please be reminded that all numbers are in our RMB and all comparisons refer to year-over-year comparisons unless otherwise stated. Please also refer to our earnings press release for detailed information of our comparative financial performance on a year-over-year basis.Please turn to slide 25. Revenue for quarter was RMB1,098 million, up 69%. Revenue from our domestic K-12 schools, including international schools, bilingual schools and kindergartens for the quarter, up 21.7% to RMB669.7 million, accounted for 60.9% of total revenue as compared to 84.7% of last year.Revenue for our international schools, up 25.3% to RMB273.9 million, primarily driven by 18.6% increase in student’s enrollment and a 5.1% increase in average tuition and fees during the comparable -- comparison period. Revenue contribution from our newly acquired semi school was 16.0 million [ph] for the quarter. Revenue for our bilingual schools up 18.5% to RMB229.8 million, driven by 12.3% increase in students enrollment and a 5.5% increase in average tuition fees.For our kindergarten, revenue was up 20.5% to RMB166 million, primarily driven by 23.1% increase in student enrollment. The average tuition and fees was down 2.8% due to the impact from newly acquired Qiqiaoban Kindergartens. Excluding Qiqiaoban impact, the average tuition fee would have increased by 3.1%. The revenue contribution from Qiqiaoban Kindergartens was RMB7.9 million for the quarter. You can refer to slide nine and -- slide 19 and 20 for more detail on the enrollment and average tuition fees.Revenue for our overseas schools, including Bournemouth, St. Michael’s and Bosworth, and also CATS for the quarter was RMB269.2 million, accounted for 23.6% of total revenue. Overseas school average number of students was 3,220.Revenue from our Complementary Education Services for the quarter up 69.7% to RMB169.1 million, accounted for 15.5% of total revenue, as compared to 15.3%. Revenue contribution from Hangzhou Impression was RMB9.7 million and DreambigCareer or DBC contributed RMB22.4 million for the quarter.On slide 26, our cost of structure. Cost of revenue for the quarter was 66.9% of total revenue, compared to 54.4% in the same quarter last fiscal year. Teaching staff cost, the primary cost contributor accounted for 29.5%, down from 34.4%. And also, the average student teacher ratio for domestic schools for the quarter was 10.9% from 9% in the same quarter of last fiscal year.Continue to slide 27. For the first fiscal quarter, our adjusted SG&A as percentage of total revenue was 18.2%, compared to 17.7%. Adjusted SG&A as percentage of revenue for domestic schools was 11.1%, down from 13%. And headquarter expenses was RMB22.4 million, compared to RMB29.8 million. As a percentage of Group revenue, headquarter SG&A expense was down 2.6% from 4.6%.On slide 28, to elaborate our adjusted SG&A as a percent of revenue by expense type. The primary increase was due to our marketing efforts to drive our enrollment. Marketing expenses was 1.1%, compared to 0.5%. Also, as a percentage of revenue, managerial staff cost was down to 9.8% from 10.2%, also professional fee down to 1.7% from 2.6%.Move to slide 29, our gross profit and margins. Gross profit for the quarter up 59.7% and gross margin was 43.9% compared to 45.6%. For domestic K-12 schools, gross profit up 23.6% and gross margin up from 47.8% to 48.5%. Overseas school’s gross profit was at $83.4 million with gross margin of 32.2%. Our complimentary education gross profit for the quarter, up 94.4% and gross margin was 38.6%, up from 33.7%.Our EBITDA -- move to slide 30, our adjusted EBITDA for the quarter up 62% and adjusted EBIT margin was 32.1%, compared to 33.5% last year. Adjusted net income for the quarter up 34.5% to $225.4 million and our adjusted net margin was 20.5%, compared to 25.8%.We are reaffirming our guidance for fiscal year 2020 on slide 32. For the fiscal year ending August 31, 2020, we expect our total revenue in the range of RMB4 billion to RMB4.1, representing a year-over-year growth of 56% to 60% based on our existing business without any potential acquisitions.We also expect our average student enrollment to be between approximately 53,200 and 53,600, representing a year-over-year increase of 14% to 15%. We expect to open seven new kindergartens during fiscal year 2020.We are also in preparation to open 13 new kindergartens and three bilingual and international schools in fiscal 2021. Beyond fiscal 2021, we have four schools and 33 kindergarten contracted for operations.Please refer to the tables in slide 34 and 35 for the condensed income statement. Slide 36 shows the reconciliation for SG&A, EBITDA and net income on a GAAP to non-GAAP results.A quick note on our cash and bank balance in slide 37. As of November 30, 2019, the company’s cash and cash equivalent and restricted cash totaled RMB2,426.6 million or US$345.1 million, as compared to RMB3,265 million as of August 31, 2019.For the first fiscal quarter ended November 30, 2019, the company’s capital expenditure was approximately $60.9 million, up 90.8% compared to last fiscal year, that including new kindergarten opening and improvement and ramp up CapEx for existing schools.This concludes my financial update. Now I will turn to Derek for his closing remarks.
Derek Feng: Thank you, Dora. Moving forward in fiscal year 2020, we are committed to the ongoing execution of our strategies in the next chapter of our transformation and growth as we work together to achieve our shared purpose to enrich student learning experience. Our team remains focused on pursuing growth opportunities, enhancing operational efficiencies and unlocking values for the benefits of our students, teachers, employees and the shareholders.This concludes our prepared remarks and I’d like to open the call for questions. Operator?
Operator: Thank you. [Operator Instructions] The first question today comes from Elsie Sheng of Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead.
Elsie Sheng: Hello, management. Thank you for taking my question. My question is about the margin outlook. Because you also mentioned that the cost structure changed with the acquisition of overseas schools. And on the one hand, the margin of the overseas school is lower than the domestic. But on the other hand, the margin of your domestic schools and also the complimentary education service is going up year-on-year. So I like to know, what do management see the margin trend of this fiscal year? And also, you mentioned that you have some initiatives to improve the operation of overseas schools. So do you have any, like, more details about how that will change the margin of overseas schools? Thank you.
Derek Feng: Okay. So let me take on the question. So -- because we are just consolidating the overseas business into the portfolio. So, therefore, today is a simple mathematical weighted average of the margins as you can find out the domestic business tend to have high margin will continue to go up and the international business because of the nature of the business model, so the margins are lower, obviously, because the margin is lower we will also paid relatively lower price.So in addition to a mathematical weighted average, which you’re seeing today and we would, obviously, confident that we can take various operating initiatives that would increase the weighted average over time in comparison to a simple mathematic average.So, for example, right now as we mentioned, we are building up shared services centers in U.K., which can -- that would serve a several acquisitions that we have acquired in U.K. over the past year. So that would take out some of the cost. At the same time, we’re also doing recruiting shareholders, that we’re taking the CATS recruiting capability to recruit international students for the other three independent colleges. So in the long run, we’re certainly hoping we will do much better than today’s mathematical weighted average. Does that answer your question?
Elsie Sheng: Okay. Understand. This is a follow up question on the UK schools. You mentioned that the centers that will cost -- save the cost for like operations and do you have more details about how much that can help on the margin?
Derek Feng: Oh! Yeah. So we can’t give you the specific numbers, but what I can tell you, if you add up all the financing people, labor costs of all the seven campuses we have in U.K., including the share of the headquarters finance staff in U.K. using that example, as well as the cost with individual systems. That will put them altogether in relationship with the shared services going forward we would see significant cost reduction.
Elsie Sheng: Okay. I see. Thank you.
Operator: The next question today comes from Christine Cho of Goldman Sachs. Please go ahead.
Christine Cho: Thank you and I am [inaudible] for the presentation. I think just a follow up to the previous question. Seems like the unallocated corporate expenses dropped quite nicely this quarter. Is it fair to read this as kind of the early results of the operational improvement initiatives that you’ve discussed in detail. And if so, is it fair to assume that it will continue to see a very similar trend throughout the year. And then, secondly, to the extent of how much you can share. Can you just elaborate on the impact of the newly acquired schools that were newly consolidated this quarter? Thank you.
Dora Li: Hi, Christine. This is Dora. Just answer your first question regarding…
Christine Cho: Hi, Dora.
Dora Li: … the so called unallocated corporate expenses. It’s actually the headquarter expenses we refer to that’s mainly the domestic or China operation headquarter expenses. So remember we have discussed our initiative to lower our SG&A expenses since the last quarter, and we are taking the right initiative to reduce the China operation all headquarter expenses, if you have come over to Foshan, so that’s our headquarter. So that’s the expense.And the so called shared services center, Derek, just mentioned, it’s truly will be an overseas cost initiative we just started after we completed the acquisition or the closing of U.K. So we’ll see some, we are expecting to see some result from -- after we complete our first phase and then second phase, setting up of the shared centers. So, does that answer your first question?
Christine Cho: Yeah. Okay. Okay. Yeah. That’s clear.
Dora Li: Yeah. So second question is also similar related to the first one. So after we gradually finished our shared service center in U.K., we’ll first complete our consolidation or improvement in finance, IT and then legal human resources. All these corporate functions for the overseas operation will be consolidated. And so we are expecting some improvement from the efficiency part after the centers are fully operations.
Christine Cho: Yeah. I see. I was more referring to kind of the sales and op impact us from the consolidation that was really done in the first quarter?
Dora Li: First quarter sales initiative?
Derek Feng: Yeah. Sorry, could you repeat your question again?
Christine Cho: Yeah. Sorry, the new consolidated schools in the first quarter of ‘20. There are two schools that are newly consolidated?
Dora Li: Oh! Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah.
Christine Cho: Yeah. Yeah. [Inaudible]
Dora Li: You’re talking about the two independent schools, which is Bosworth and St. Michaels. Yes, those two…
Christine Cho: Yes. Yeah.
Dora Li: … schools are consolidated in the first quarter. Yeah. You’re right.
Christine Cho: Yeah. So I was just wondering what’s roughly the size of the impact on sales and op during this quarter from that consolidation?
Dora Li: Actually the three independent schools are doing well on track in terms of our expectations. I think that the only -- the overall margin from the overseas segment the impact -- the only impact was from CATS, because first quarter CATS has some impact from student intake during some macroeconomic or political reasons for the other three independent schools they are doing okay.
Christine Cho: Okay. Thank you.
Operator: Again…
Derek Feng: Yeah. So, basically, sorry, the two schools are generally they are very small, didn’t really add too much to the first quarter. Those two schools add together is approximately 800 students in total. So therefore they’re not that material from overall perspective.
Jerry He: To give you some idea, this is Jerry, just give you some idea of the size of the two schools. Last year the internal revenue they did about approximately £12 million. So if you allocated first quarter, I mean, those two schools are reasonably stable, so you can figure out what’s possible first quarter is.
Christine Cho: Okay. Thank you.
Operator: [Operator Instructions] As there are no further questions, this concludes our question-and-answer session. I would like to turn the conference back over to Derek Feng for any closing remarks.
Derek Feng: Thank you very much for joining the conference call. Please feel to contact us if you have any further questions. We wish everyone a good day. Thank you.
Operator: The conference is now concluded. Thank you for attending today’s presentation. You may now disconnect.
